body.p:
To his Excellency T E Bramlett
Gov of Kentucky

your Petitioners William S Warren and William P Warren would respectfully state to your Excellency that at the fall term 1862 of the Taylor circuit court the Grand jury of said county found a true bill against your Petitioner William S Warren for an alledged Breach of the Peace committed as alledged in Said county your Petitioners state that that William S. Warren as required by law executed a bond to the Comonwealth of Kentucky in the sum of three hundred dollars with William P Warren his father as his Surety for his appearance at the next term of said Court your petitioners State that said William S Warren did attend Said Court, and said cause was continued by the Comth and your petitioner William S Warren was permitted to stand on his bond for his appearance at the next term of said court your Petitioners State that in the fall of 1862 in Octo your petitioner William S Warren who was then a soldier in the union army was attacked by a band of Guerillas under the command of Capt Edwards of Green County and was Severely wounded being Shot four times and is a cripple for life your Petitioners state that he was compelled to remain at home for Several months on account of said wounds, but that he was So far recovered as to be able to go to his command and that at the March term of said court he was with his command and could not attend said court as is shown by the statement of Brig. Gen. Ward herewith filed He states that said bond was forfeited and that at the September term 1864 of said court that said William S Warren was required by the Court to pay fifteen dollars of said bond
and the balance of said bond was remitted by the court your Petitioners state that the non attendance of said William S Warren was unavoidable on his part and although the amount is Small your petitioner states that William S Warren is wholly unable to pay the same that owing to his wounds before mentioned that he is unable to support himself and that himself and family are supported by his father William P. Warren and your Petitioners state that Said William P Warren is severely afflicted and that he has been confined to his house for months past and that owing to the high price of Provisions and the great Scarcity of the Same that it is difficult for them to procure the necessaries of life & that if they are compelled to pay the same it will take from them nearly all the money they have with which to buy provisions & they can not get the necessaries of life without money
Wherefore they pray your Excellency to remit said Sum of fifteen dollars & your Petitioners will as in duty bound ever pray &c

William S ^his X mark^ Warren
William P ^his X Mark^ Warren
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 5th day of Oct 1864 by William S & W P Warren
D S Towles Clk G. C. C.
your Excellency will please direct your Answer to D T Towles Greensburg Ky

I know Wm S Warren, he was with me in March 1864. in the state of Tennessee as assistant waggon-master, & remained with me as such for near three months and left me about the last of april or first of May -- had he attempted to return, to the march court of the the Taylor circuit court I would not ^have^ permitted him to have done so but would have arrested him & compelled him to remain until the expiration of his term of service which expired or ended the latter part of april 1864

Taylor Cir Ct
vs
Wm S & Wm P Warren
$300
Remit
8th Oct/64
